Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Postdoctoral Fellowships in Biology combine research and training components to prepare young scientists for careers in biology and require a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science and engineering. The fellowships advance NSF efforts to diversify the STEM workforce now and in the future. The research plan for this fellowship to David Gonthier asks if functional traits and genetic relatedness of crop diversity influence pollination, pest control, and yield in order to understand the ecological consequences of biodiversity. The research and training are being conducted at the University of California, Berkeley and the University of GÃ¶ttingen, Germany with sponsoring scientists Drs. Claire Kremen and Teja Tscharntke. Training goals include learning new phylogenetic and functional analyses. Undergraduates from under-represented groups are involved in field research and meta-analysis. A short term visit to Germany adds an international dimension to the research and training.

While increased species diversity has been shown to improve multiple ecosystem functions, few studies have investigated how functional traits and genetic relatedness of species contribute to these diversity effects and specifically in agricultural ecosystems where functions may be of economic value. For example, it may be that planting fields with distantly related plant species improves natural resistance to crop-specialist pests. Or perhaps increasing the range of seasonal flowering traits amongst plants might maximizes pollinator persistence and crop pollination. Although strawberry (Rosaceae: Fragaria x ananassa) can self-pollinate, marketable fruit yield may depend on pollinator diversity as flowers pollinated by multiple species are more-fully developed. This fellowship research is being conducted in and around the Salinas and Central Valleys of California, among the most productive regions of the U.S. for strawberry production as well as salad greens, Brassica crops, spinach, and tomatoes. In large scale California agroecosystems, strawberries are grown in monocultures in order to mechanize production and facilitate ease of harvest. However, in smaller scale systems, and in other regions, strawberries are intercropped with a wide variety of other crops. Recent research of such agroecosystems has demonstrated that intercropping with strawberries does not limit strawberry yields. Using field experiments and meta-analysis of the scientific literature, this research seeks to determine if functional traits and genetic relatedness of crop diversity impacts the focal crop pollination and limits crop-damage by pests and diseases. Finally, this project combines this information to identify potential trade-offs or synergies between pollination, pest control, and yield.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pests and pathogens play important roles in structuring the communities of plants and inflicting economic damage to crops in agriculture. In natural communities, it is thought that abundant species will be at a disadvantage because pests and pathogens have many hosts to attack. In agriculture, this also appears true, as monocultures are often highly susceptible to pest and disease outbreaks. Thus, mixing crops in polycultures is one way to reduce the impact of pests on crops. Nonetheless, not all polycultures are successful because many pests and pathogens can consume multiple plant species, often plant species that are closely related. In some natural systems, researchers show that phylogenetically rare species – species that are surrounded by distantly related species – are damaged less.  Given this, it is hypothesized that planting crops that are distantly related best optimizes polycultures.

The goal of this research was to test this hypothesis in several different crop diversification techniques. To do so, I led a team of undergraduate students, graduate students, postdocs, and faculty to carry out meta-analytical research and field research. 1) Using meta-analysis of the agricultural literature, we collected data from crop rotation studies to ask if crops planted in sequences that were more distantly related had fewer pests and diseases than rotations that were more closely related. 2) Using GIS mapping techniques, we asked if farm landscapes with more distantly related crops had fewer pests and diseases than landscapes with more closely related crops.

Contrasting over 300 comparisons of different crop rotations, we found that the 54% of comparisons showed that crop rotations with distantly related crops had fewer pests and diseases and less damage than did rotations with closely related crops. Using GIS and field surveys of strawberry pests in the Central Coast region of California, our preliminary results show that crop phylogenetic relatedness to strawberries at the landscape scale was a significant predictor of 6 pests and diseases (out of 12). However, of those significant relationships, three were positive, and three were negative, suggesting an inconsistent response of strawberry pests and diseases to crop phylogenetic relatedness.

These results suggest that the analysis of crop phylogenetic relatedness is a useful tool for designing crop diversification schemes aimed at reducing some pests and diseases. However, not all pests and diseases respond in a predictable pattern.

This research also led to outreach materials that were created and piloted with farmers to describe their ‘phylogenetic farmscapes’ – the phylogenetic relatedness of all crops in their field. This tool can be used to help visualize crop phylogenetic relatedness in space and time, which could ultimately be used to help farmers make decisions of how and when to plant different crops. Further, this research supported the research experience for nine undergraduate students, 7 of which were from under-represented groups.
